868586 old after enduring incredible sufferings, he won the pity of the gods and was raised with his subjects to heaven : <ab>accord.</ab> to <ls>MBh. ii, 489</ls> &c., his performance of the <s1 slp1="rAja-sUya">Rāja-sūya</s1> sacrifice was the cause of his elevation, and in the <s1 slp1="Etareya-brAhmaRa">Aitareya-Brāhmaṇa</s1> quite another legend is told about him See under <s>SunaHSepa</s>, <pcol>p. 1082, col. 3</pcol> : in later legends <s1 slp1="hari-Scandra">Hari-ścandra</s1> is represented as insidiously induced by <s1 slp1="nArada">Nārada</s1> to relate his actions with unbecoming pride, whereupon he was degraded from <s1 slp1="svarga">Svarga</s1>, one stage at each sentence, till stopping in time and doing homage to the gods he was fixed with his capital in mid-air <pb n="1291,1"/>;
868586 new after enduring incredible sufferings, he won the pity of the gods and was raised with his subjects to heaven : <ab>accord.</ab> to <ls>MBh. ii, 489</ls> &c., his performance of the <s1 slp1="rAja-sUya">Rāja-sūya</s1> sacrifice was the cause of his elevation, and in the <s1 slp1="Etareya-brAhmaRa">Aitareya-Brāhmaṇa</s1> quite another legend is told about him, see under <s>SunaHSepa</s>, <pcol>p. 1082, col. 3</pcol> : in later legends <s1 slp1="hari-Scandra">Hari-ścandra</s1> is represented as insidiously induced by <s1 slp1="nArada">Nārada</s1> to relate his actions with unbecoming pride, whereupon he was degraded from <s1 slp1="svarga">Svarga</s1>, one stage at each sentence, till stopping in time and doing homage to the gods he was fixed with his capital in mid-air <pb n="1291,1"/>;
